ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Two main issues with this course:1) I covers too much material in too little time.2) There is gap in knowledge between SOM and F&ES students. F&ES students could benefit from more detailed explanations in class, but the class speed does not allow for this.

The course heavily depended on utilizing excel spreadsheets and modeling, both of which I don't know much about. There was a distinct difference between skill sets between FES students and SOM students. I'm not sure how much I got out of the class because i had little to contribute to my group work and felt like I was free loading because of my inexperience with modeling.
Games were interesting. Rest of course was somewhat cursory.

This class would have been great if it weren't so short. Maybe I'm just not used to a 1/2 semester class. This is a very interesting subject it would have been great to go more deeply into some of the material, instead of just giving a quick and superficial view.
I have answered this course evaluation before.
Very knowledgeable instructor. Group work were valuable learning experiences.
Hands down, working through the respective course games.

The introduction to the business side of energy. It was a good follow-up to Energy Systems Analysis last Fall. The course provided a solid and thorough overview of the key laws and business principles underlying energy markets.
the lectures were interesting.
The OPEC and electricity games provided a very tangible manner in which to learn the course material.
The market exercises were great, very well thought out, programmed, etc.Also, the visits by working professionals were great.
OPEC and electricity games. There's no better way to understand the dynamics of electricity markets/cartels than to actually get involved.
you get a glimpse of the way energy markets work
Guest speakers

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Make it a semester long course, or cover less material. Some material is difficult to follow for F&ES students (such as commodities trading).Make group work due on Thursday nights, not Friday nights. Quality collaborative work goes out the window when people have social lives on Friday nights.

I wish it had gone into more detail about the market considerations surrounding new and alternative energy, like wind and solar. The course stuck mainly to very traditional energy markets, and the electricity section did't really discuss in detail the types of issues surrounding energy efficiency and renewable energy. Since that's more the direction I'm heading, I would have really appreciated more discussion around demand side management and renewable energy markets.Also, it was sometimes difficult to follow the concepts presented, as many of them relied heavily on SOM background knowledge. Even though I had taken the Economics foundations course at FES and have a pretty strong grasp economics, some of the so-called "basic economics" concepts discussed in class were totally foreign to me and many other FES students. Since this is a joint class, it would be helpful if the professor knew better exactly what level the FES students were at, so that he/she could either provide background info in class or some sort of supplementary material out of class for us to get caught up with the SOM students. For instance, a lot of the concepts used in the oil markets game were totally new, and so FES students had to rely heavily on SOM teammates to do a lot of the work (and hope they did it correctly!).
explaining how the games are going to work before they start. explaining how to model for results.
Please devote a greater portion of the course to renewable energy.
Would be great if it were narrower and deeper maybe.

Should be a full semester course. Would have been great to spend more time on each of the topics - oil/gas, electricity. Didn't have much time at all on renewables - a real disappointment. Also, would be great to add a field trip to this class - possibly to New York to visit with traders or possibly to a gasoline blending station, natural gas gathering spot/flow gate etc.

The lectures weren't too interesting. It was assumed that students knew how to do excel modeling to complete the assignments which was not true for many of the FES students. As a result, I didn't get as much out of it. A tutorial onn how to do the modeling at the start of the class would have made a huge difference.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Brian is great.
Did not seek out instructor. TA was incredibly responsive and helpful.
Both were available and helpful.
available when solicited.
Great availability and quality of help from both the instructor and the TA.
N/A
Both were always available, super helpful. Prof. Campbell took this course over from Erin Mansur and should only get better as he takes ownership of the material, updates it etc.
the TA was very helpful

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Electricity markets, oil markets, natural gas markets, regulation, trading, etc.
In seeking to gain strong familiarity in energy markets, this course was incredibly valuable.
Studying energy policy, so an understanding of markets and market policies is important.

If you are interested in climate change or energy policy, you do NOT need to take this course, note you do NOT need to take this course!! This course is about commodities trading, not about energy policy in the sense one might think. Do not waste your time if you are not interested in cartels and oil markets and how electricity is traded.
Energy impacts water management, but this class focused primarily on electricity and gas markets, which are not very relevant.
Following an internship in carbon financing and renewable energy technologies in India, I was interested in further pursuing my studies in energy.
Fits in peripherally. I took this to gain some vocabulary around energy issues, and it was effective for that.
I'm focused on energy so this was invaluable. I've spent a lot of time looking at policy so understanding how things actually work on the ground was great.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Studying energy at F&ES.
Very interested in energy policy and wanted a better understanding of energy markets so as to be able to better understand policy.
I thought I would need it because it had "energy" in the title and that's not a good reason to have taken it.
i was interested in the relationship between energy and water resource management, this class did not cover this topic.
I am aiming to secure a research or analyst position in energy and climate change policy next year and was interested in educating myself on energy markets.
See above.
See above.
I am interested in energy and environmental markets

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: I was a little disappointed. Too much material too fast, so I don't feel like I learned an enormous amount. Group work was difficult, particularly as an F&ES student I felt like I had little to contribute compared to SOM students. All the models were designed by SOM students it seems,with F&ES students simply trying to understand the models.
Exceeded expectations.
Mostly - I would have liked more discussion about energy efficiency and renewable energy.
NO.
no. I wanted to participate more in the group work but as an FES with no backgroun in excel modeling, was at a severe loss.
Yes.
Yes.

Mostly - again, should be spread over an entire semester, though. Also, getting a bit more direction/help on the electricity game would have been great. Wasn't until the end of the game that we started to get a handle on how to really manipulate prices.
No!

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: I was a little disappointed. Too much material too fast, so I don't feel like I learned an enormous amount. Group work was difficult, particularly as an F&ES student I felt like I had little to contribute compared to SOM students. All the models were designed by SOM students it seems, with F&ES students simply trying to understand the models.
Exceeded.
Mostly - I would have liked more discussion about energy efficiency and renewable energy.
No.
no.
Almost - I learned a lot about energy markets but would have loved to have had renewable energies play a bigger role in the course.
Yes.
Mostly - see above. Again, more time on renewables would have been really, really valuable. Next year - please reserve more time for this content!
No - I didn't get much of out of. Crammed for the final but didnt feel like I learned much in the class.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It is always beneficial to learn how to work as a team, even in the most difficult circumstances.That being said, some people become leaders, others are active but just trying to keep up, others simply don't care. Having to submit collaborative material on Friday nights is a bad idea, people have social lives that take precedence.
Combined and complemented strengths and weaknesses.

Advantages were that it provided a good opportunity to learn from SOM students who had a much better understanding of many of the Excel and financing concepts necessary to play the games well. I learned a lot from my oil market group.Disadvantages were that if you didn't get a team of people willing to work/help the team, it was very easy to stuck having to take up a lot of work yourself. My electricity markets team was not very motivated to put a lot of effort into developing a strategy, and as such we didn't do as well as a team, and I didn't learn as much from the experience.

Some people pull their weight better than others--the usual. Also the business students are really valuable b/c they know how to use excel and do trending really well. Wish FES students could learn that too (perhaps as a separate lab when these exercises are introduced)?
advantages, i learned more about excel modeling.disadvantages, i had little to contribute and would have drowned without the help of my group mates.

One major disadvantage was having a group of individuals unwilling to participate in the game, creating a very unfair workload.One advantage was being in a group of business school students and, as a forestry student, being able to learn from them.
Group work is a very big part of this class. It was interesting to work with SOM students, who are like a different species.
Discussing strategy with the OPEC and electricity games was essential to determining the best path forward. Also simulated the difficulty in keeping a cartel together.
It was good

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take the class, it won't be a waste of time, but just don't get your hopes up too high.
Get to class early on the first day! The seats fill up quickly!
if you aren't directly interested in electricity or gas markets, don't take this course.
Do all the readings, get clarity on the rules of the games - what you can/can't do - at the beginning, don't wait 'til the last minute to determine your bidding strategy in either game.
Even if you are interested in energy, re consider if this class will be helpful to you. A lot of it is review of energy policy and basic econ.
